Graphical abstract A series of FeOx/Ti-MCM-41 mesostructured catalysts were synthesized and characterized by the X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Mössbauer spectroscopy. The surface reducibility and acidity of the catalysts were measured by temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (TPR-H2) and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPR-NH3) methods. Incorporating Ti4+ in the MCM-41 framework and loading Fe2O3 in the surface of the catalysts would create the acid sites and enhance the surface oxygen reducibility. Most of Fe3+ ions were highly dispersed on the surface and some were inserted into the framework of the support with different structural environments. The amount of the Fe3+ ions locating around the structural defects increased as the Fe content increased. In a biphasic reaction system (n-hexadecane/acetonitrile), the oxidation/elimination of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) could correlate perfectly with the surface acidity and the amount of iron ions around the structural defects of the catalysts. The reactivity of sulfur compounds decreased with increasing of the steric hindrance, showing an order as: DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT. In the presence of catalyst and oxidant, the polar/non-polar biphasic reaction system developed herein could effectively oxidize the sterically hindered sulfur compounds and simultaneously extracted the produced sulfones from oil phase into polar phase. Keywords Mesoporous catalyst H2O2 Oxidative desulfurization Diesel 1 Introduction New technology and processes for deep desulfurization of combustion fuels are stringently demanded because of sulfur in transportation fuels leading to serious environmental problems, such as air pollution and acid rain. Many countries have made new legislations to minimize sulfur content in fuels lower than 15ppm [1,2]. As a consequence, in the petrochemical industry, special measures such as increasing the operation temperature and pressure have to be taken to satisfy the new environmental laws for the existed hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process. However, severe modifications of the reaction conditions of the HDS may increase operation expenses and alter the final products specifications such as aromatics content, cetane number, and others [3]. It is known that when total sulfur content in diesel is reduced to approximately 500ppm, most of the organosulfur compounds remaining in the hydrotreated oil are sterically hindered organosulfur compounds like dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT). If the conventional HDS is used to further reduce sulfur content from 500ppm to 15ppm, it is estimated that the volume of the commercial catalyst used in this process will be increased by 3.2 times under the same operation condition [4], which increases the cost and finally the fuel price. These have motivated the development of alternative technologies for the removal of heterocyclic organosulfur compounds from fuels under an economical and moderate operation condition. Compared to the conventional HDS, the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) has several distinguished advantages, including soft reaction conditions (ambient pressure and temperature lower than 100°C), without consumption of expensive hydrogen, and ability for desulfurization of sterically hindered sulfur compounds [5]. In the ODS process, sulfur compounds are oxidized to their corresponding sulfones; the physicochemical properties of sulfones are considerably different from their precursors. As sulfones are soluble in proper polar solvent, they can be easily removed by extraction [6]. Different catalysts were reported for the oxidation/elimination of sulfur compounds from diesel using ODS technique. These included transition metal oxides (Ti, Mo, Co, Fe, V, W) as active phases dispersed on proper support [7]. Alina-liva et al. reported that W-, V- and Mo-containing layered double hydroxides were active for catalytic oxidation of thioethers and thiophene derivatives with H2O2. They found that the catalyst performances strongly depended on the nature of the anion species intercalated in the interlayer gallery and the W-based LDH was more active and more stable than the V-LDH and Mo-LDH catalysts [8]. A series of bimetallic Cu–Fe/TiO2 catalysts were tested for sulfur compounds removal from fuel. The 2.0wt% Cu–Fe/TiO2 was confirmed as the most efficient photocatalyst for the conversion of sulfur species under mild conditions in the presence of hydrogen peroxide [9]. In the design of new catalyst support for ODS reaction, taking the large molecular size of the aromatic organosulfur compounds into account, great attention was paid to mesoporous materials like MCM-41 solids which possess large surface area and big pore diameter [10–18]. The transition metal incorporation in the MCM-41 and SBA-15 structure allows obtaining active catalysts for sulfur oxidation in fuel [19–23]. Some Ti-related mesoporous solids were tensely investigated for the oxidation reactions including their application to ODS processes, for example TS-1 [24–26], Ti–HMS silica [27,28], a Ti–HMS/TS-1 composite [29], Ti-MCM-48 [30], and TiO2 nanotubes [31]. The present work focuses on the development of a biphasic ODS process by combination of catalysis, oxidation, and extraction to remove the sterically hindered organosulfur compounds from fuels, aiming at ultraclean fuel production. The mesostructured FeOx/Ti-MCM-41 catalysts were synthesized for the oxidation removal of DBTs (DBT, 4-MDBT, and 4,6-DMDBT) in a model diesel. Oxidation/elimination reactions of DBTs were performed in a biphasic system consisting of an oil phase (n-hexadecane) and a polar solvent (acetonitrile) where H2O2 was used as oxidant. The effects of reaction temperature and time, Fe loading, and surface acidity on the catalytic performance of the catalysts were investigated. Correlation of the surface Fe active phase and surface acidity with the ODS activity of the catalysts were reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MCM-41 support The mesoporous support was synthesized by the surfactant-templated route using alkoxides of silicon and titanium as Si and Ti precursors and a low concentration of surfactant (cetyltrimethylammonium chloride) as structural template. A typical synthetic method consisted of several steps: (1) 6.5ml of ammonium hydroxide was added to a stirring mixture of 486ml deionized water and 33.16ml of a solution of cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (25wt%, Aldrich, noted as CTACl). This mixture was stirred for 2h at a rotation rate 900rpm. (2) To the above mixture, 42.5ml of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) was slowly added during 2h; (3) 5ml of titanium (IV) propoxide was slowly added and the mixture was stirred for 2h. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to approximately 9 using ammonium hydroxide; (4) the above mixture was stirring for 24h and was then refluxed at 40°C for 72h. Finally white gel was obtained after the solvents were evaporated at 40°C. The resulting solid was washed with deionized water using a Buchner funnel until the pH of the wash water was close to 7. The excess humidity of the resulting solid was removed by heating in an oven at 60°C for 8h and the samples were calcined at 500°C in air with an increasing heating rate 1°C/min. The solid material was noted as Ti-MCM-41. 2.2 Synthesis of Fe/Ti-MCM-41 catalyst The iron oxide was introduced on the Ti-MCM-41 support by incipient impregnation method using Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution as Fe precursor. Fe content in the catalysts varied from 5wt% to 10, 15, 20 and 25wt%. The catalysts were then dried in an oven at 40°C for 8h and calcined in a muffle furnace in air at 550°C for 4h. The resulting catalysts were named as Fe/TiM-5, Fe/Ti-10, Fe/TiM-15, Fe/TiM-20 and Fe/TiM-25, where the number represents the weight percentage of iron and TiM represents Ti modified MCM-41. All catalysts had a reddish-brown mass tone, ranging from light to reddish brown as iron content increased. 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis The crystalline structures of the catalysts were analyzed using powder X-ray diffraction technique on a Siemens D500 diffractometer coupled to a tube with copper anode and Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å). The measurements were carried out at ambient temperature with 35kV and 20mA. For analyzing the Ti-MCM-41 support, X-ray diffraction patterns was recorded in a low angle range between 1 and 10°. The wide XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded in a 2θ range between 5° and 70° with a step of 0.02° and a measuring time of 2.67s at each point. 2.3.2 Textural property measurement The loops of nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples were obtained at 77K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 apparatus, using N2 as adsorbent. Before the adsorption-desorption experiments, all the samples were treated under vacuum at 100°C for 2h and thermally heated at 300°C for 20h. The surface area data were calculated according to the model of Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). The pore size distribution was calculated by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model from the desorption isotherms. 2.3.3 Reducibility measurement The reducibility of the Fe/TiM catalysts was measured with an equipment TPD/TPR 2900 Micromeritics. The samples were degassed in N2 flow at 400°C for 1h. Then it was cooled to ambient temperature. A flow of mixture (10% hydrogen − 90% helium) was fed into the TPR system where 200mg of catalysts were loaded in a U-type glass tube. The temperature was increased up to 800°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The signal was recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3.4 Surface acidity measurement The surface acidity of the catalysts was analyzed by temperature-programed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) experiments on a TPD/TPR 2900 Micromeritics coupled with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 200mg of sample were loaded in a U-type glass tube and was thermally treated in air from ambient temperature up to 300°C at which the treatment maintained for 1h. Subsequently, it was cooled to 100°C. Afterwards, NH3 flow was fed into the sample bed for adsorption for 30min till saturated. The temperature was increased with a rate of 10°C/min up to 800°C. The desorbed ammonia signal was recorded by the TCD. 2.3.5 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The TEM micrographics were obtained with a high resolution microscope (HRTEM Jeol 2100F), using a light-field emitter and 200kV of acceleration. The resolution was 1.86Å. It connected with a detector of energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) for surface element analysis in the selected areas. 2.3.6 Mössbauer spectroscopy The Mössbauer spectra of the catalysts were obtained at ambient temperature in a spectrometer (Austin Scientific Associates S-600 model) with a source 57Co of 0.925 GBq (25 mCi) in a rhodium matrix. The isomeric shift was reported with respect to α-Fe, the spectra were fitted using program NORMOS. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Experiments for the oxidation of DBTs were carried out using a model diesel mixture consisting of 100ppm of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 150ppm of 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), and 250ppm of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) giving a total 500ppm sulfur compounds (noted as DBTs) in n-hexadecane. In a three-necked flask, equipped with a condenser, agitator and thermometer, 0.03g of catalyst was added to 30ml of n-hexadecane containing 500ppm of DBTs, and 30ml of acetonitrile. H2O2 (30%) was added into the above mixture. The reaction was carried out at different temperature with stirring at atmospheric pressure. The oxidation/elimination of DBTs was monitored every 5min for the first 30min of reaction, and after then every 10min by taking an aliquot of 0.2ml from oil phase (n-hexadecane), which was filtered with a Millipore of 0.2μm in diameter and was analyzed by gas chromatography (Chromatograph Shimadzu GC-8a) equipped with a flame photometric detector (FPD) and SE-30 column (100% dimethylpolysiloxane). The results were tabulated and recorded graphically. The DBTs oxidation versus reaction time was determined according to the following equation: CDBTs (%)=(Co −Ct)/Co. Where Co is the concentration at time zero and Ct is the DBTs concentration at time t. Concentrations of sulfones in acetonitrile were determined by a similar way. 3 Results 3.1 Structure analysis — X ray diffraction The XRD patterns of Fe/TiM catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . For the Ti-MCM-41 solid, in the low 2θ angle range, several XRD peaks with different intensities were observed at 2θ=2.2°, 3.6°, 4.7°, and 5.5°, which corresponded to the reflection of the (100), (110), (200) and (210) planes of mesoporous MCM-41 with hexagonal symmetry, respectively (Fig. 1a). The intensities of these diffraction peaks decreased as iron was impregnated, and the peak position slightly shifted to left region, indicating that some iron ions were incorporated into the framework of MCM-41, diminishing the mesostructural regularity. In Fig. 1b, the XRD patterns exhibited a wide peak with low intensity at around 2θ=23.5° in all the samples. It was assigned to nanoparticles of amorphous silica. When Fe content was 5wt%, no XRD peaks related to iron oxides were detectable, indicating that these Fe ions were highly dispersed on the surface or inserted into the framework of the support. As Fe content was greater than 5wt%, several peaks appeared and their intensity increased with the iron content. These peaks appeared at 24°, 34°, 41°, 49.3°, 54°, 64°, corresponding to reflection of the planes (012), (104), (113), (024), (214) of the α-Fe2O3 phase (JCPDS No. 033-0664); other peaks at 30.3°, 35.9,°, 43.9°, 53.9°, 57.5°, 62.5° corresponded to the reflection of the planes (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) of the γ-Fe2O3 phase [32]. These results showed that both γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3 phases coexisted in the surface of Ti-MCM-41 support [33]. It is noted that the main XRD peak of anatase TiO2 also located at approximately 2θ=25°, a small amount of anatase was probably deposited in the surface of Ti-MCM-41 support, too. 3.2 Textural properties — N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms Fig. 2 shows the loops of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the profiles of pore size distribution of the Fe/TiM catalysts. The loops of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms belonged to type IV according to the IUPAC classification, typical of mesoporous materials. They were distinguished in two zones, the first, at the low relative pressure region, indicated the N2 monolayer formation on the surface followed by multilayer formation of adsorbent. The second zone was observed at moderate relative pressure region. There was an inflection point at P/P0 =0.4, indicating the capillary condensation in mesopores. Above this point, the multilayer adsorption in external surface took place. The pore size distribution was shown at inset of Fig. 2, which was a narrow monomodal, indicating high homogeneity of the pore structure [34]. Table 1 shows the data of the textural parameters of the materials. After iron doping, the Fe/TiM catalysts retained single pore distribution with a peak maximum centered between 21.6 and 24Å. Both surface area and pore volume decreased with an increasing content of Fe. 3.3 Surface oxygen reducibility — TPR-H2 Fig. 3 shows the TPR-H2 profiles of the Fe/TiM catalysts. During TPR-H2 procedure, H2 consumption was not observed for the Fe/TiM-0 sample (not shown), confirming that the TPR peaks in the Fe/TiM catalysts belonged to the reduction of iron oxides. One peak between 100°C and 150°C was observed. Increasing the iron content led to its peak area increasing and shifted the peak maximum to lower temperatures. This peak was assigned to the reduction of Fe3+ species located on the surface. Peak position shift to lower temperature region indicated the interaction between Fe2O3 and support becoming weak at higher Fe content. Another peak appeared at round 483°C. The area and position of this peak did not altered with the Fe content, indicating that it was related to the reduction of Fe3+ inserted in the MCM-41 framework. It was noteworthy that at low iron content, most iron ions were inserted into the framework of the MCM-41 structure. The iron ions in the framework of the MCM-41 reached almost maximum and then the extra were dispersed on the surface. The TPR results confirmed the presence of Fe species both in surface and framework of the support. 3.4 Surface acidity — TPD-NH3 The surface acidity of the catalysts was measured by TPD-NH3 method. Usually the temperature corresponding to peak maxima indicated the acidity strength (weak, medium and high), and the peak areas corresponded to the number of acid sites [35–37]. Table 2 shows the temperatures corresponding to the peak maxima and the total acidity calculated from the areas under the curves of NH3 desorption. The TPD-NH3 profiles of Ti-MCM-41 (Fe/TiM-0) showed two peaks that corresponded to the acid sites with weak and high strength, respectively. A greater number of total acid sites were formed in the catalysts containing higher content of Fe, indicating that the Fe content was principally responsible for the acidity increment. Because the surface area of the catalysts was gradually reduced and the amount of acidity was increased with increasing content of Fe, the density of the acid site was significantly increased after Fe impregnation; for example, the acid site density of the Fe/TiM-25 catalyst was 0.91μmoles NH3/(g·m2), which was approximately 7 times greater relative to the pure support which had an acid site density 0.13μmoles NH3/(g·m2). Although an increase of iron content could increase the number of acid sites, it did not significantly alter the acid strength as evidenced by the unchanged peak position in TPD-NH3 profiles of the catalysts. The surface acidity in the catalysts was created by the formation FeOx species in the surface and the possible Fe-O-Ti and Fe-O-Si bonds in the framework of the support [36]. 3.5 Morphological feature and surface element composition — TEM and EDS analysis Fig. 4 shows the TEM images and the EDS spectra in the selected areas of the Ti-MCM-41 support and Fe/TiM-15 catalyst. For the Ti-MCM-41 solid, well ordered hexagonal mesopore arrangements were clearly observed, confirming the material type MCM-41 [23]. The observed spots on the Ti-MCM-41 sample were probably attributed to TiO2 clusters, which were not incorporated to the network, but formed as fine agglomerates of anatase TiO2 on the surface of MCM-41 solid. In the Fe/TiM-15 catalyst, some spherical particles with diameter 50–60nm were observed on the surface of Ti-MCM-41. These spherical particles were assigned to principally FeOx oxides. In Fig. 4a (Fe/TiM-0), the EDS spectrum shows Si, O and Ti elements, indicating that the solid consisted of Si and O elements in the surface where Ti were dispersed within the MCM-41 structure. In Fig. 4b, for the same Fe/TiM-15 sample, one selected area was analyzed; Fe and O elements were detected on the surface, but Ti element was not detected in this particle, indicating that Ti-MCM-41 was covered by nanoparticles of iron oxides in that area. Fig. 4c confirmed that O, Si, Ti, and Fe elements were present in another selected area in the Fe/TiM-15 catalyst. Atom concentrations in the selected area obtained by EDS in the Fe/TiM-0 and Fe/TiM-15 samples are reported in Table 3 . These solids were quite clean as carbon species were not detectable. 3.6 Fe chemical environments — Mössbauer spectroscopy Fig. 5 shows a set of Mössbauer spectra of the Fe/TiM catalysts. All the Mössbauer spectra could be deconvoluted into two central doublets or one sexlet and two central doublets, depending of the Fe content. These indicated that the Fe/TM catalysts contained different FeOx phases and Fe ions had different coordinates and chemical environments. For most of the catalysts (Fe content was lower than or equal to 20wt%), Mössbauer spectra showed only a pair central doublets with different parameters, indicating that Fe3+ ions had a high spin in octahedral coordinates [38,39]. The Mössbauer parameters of the Fe/TiM samples including the isomer shift (δ), quadrupole splitting (Δ), hyperfine magnetic field (Bhf), and the surface Fe ions identification are reported in Table 4 . The presence of the pair doublets (D1 and D2) suggested that there two types of Fe ions with different chemical environments: D1 had the lower value of quadrupole splitting, therefore, some Fe3+ ions were slightly distorted and located away of structural defects, i.e., oxygen vacancies; while D2 had a greater splitting quadrupole, indicating that some Fe3+ ions were strongly distorted and located around oxygen defects [40–42]. For the catalyst with greater Fe content i.e., 25wt% Fe, additional to the central doublets, there was a sexlet in the Mössbauer spectrum (Fig. 5e). It was ascribed to the Fe3+ in the octahedral coordinates in α-Fe2O3 phase. These results indicated that in the Fe/TiM samples, some Fe ions were inserted in the framework of MCM-41 and others existed in a separated γ-Fe2O3 and/or α-Fe2O3 phases. These Fe3+ ions with different coordinates and chemical environments exhibited different reducibility, which were in good agreement with the results revealed by the TPR profiles. 3.7 Catalytic activity — oxidative desulfurization tests Fig. 6 shows the total removal of 500ppm sulfur compounds versus reaction time under near natural condition (pH=7, T=60°C, 0.9ml H2O2, and 0.03g Fe/TiM-15 catalyst). In the first 25min, the ODS rates were rapid and they varied with different sulfur compounds. The order of reactivity was DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT. The reactivity was related to the steric hindrance resulted from the presence of methyl groups in the aromatic rings [43,44]. The sulfur compounds with greater steric hindrance were difficult to be oxidized. Under this condition, the maximum oxidation/elimination of DBT using Fe/TiM-15 catalyst was approximately 81.4%. The effect of reaction temperature on the oxidation/elimination of DBTs was evaluated. Fig. 7 shows the dependence of the oxidation/elimination of the DBTs at different temperatures. For the same catalyst, the oxidation/elimination of DBTs slightly decreased with the increasing reaction temperature from 60°C to 70 and 80°C. This was probably due to the H2O2 partial decomposition at higher temperature, which was unfavorable to the formation of active oxygen species in the surface of the catalyst. The DBT conversion was only between 20% and 40% in a temperature range between 30 and 60°C. Therefore, in the present work, 60°C was the optimal reaction temperature for DBT oxidation. For different catalysts, the oxidation activity at the same temperature increased significantly as the Fe content increased from 5 to 15wt%. As the catalysts with Fe content higher than 15wt%, the catalytic activity was not obviously increased. In one hand, the catalyst with higher Fe content could result in poor dispersion or formation of aggregates of FeOx in the surface; in the other hand, high Fe content could cover both the TiO2 nanoparticles on the surface and the Ti4+ coordinated in the network of MCM-41. This may reduce the hydrophobicity induced by the covering of surface Ti4+. Hence, the oxidation activity did not linearly increase with Fe content as it was greater than 15wt%. 4 Discussion In the present work, oxidation/elimination of DBTs in a biphasic system consisted of the oxidation of DBTs and the extraction of sulfones (BTSs). Several parameters including oxidant, catalyst, surface acidity, reaction temperature and time were proven to play important roles in the oxidation of DBTs. The creation of surface acid sites of the catalysts was related to Fe3+ in the surface. Fig. 8 shows the correlation of surface acidity with the Fe content of the catalysts. The surface acidity of the catalysts was almost linearly increased with the Fe content. Fig. 9 shows the ODS conversion as a function of the surface acidity. Results indicated that surface acidity served as reaction centers in the ODS reactions. The Mössbauer spectra shown in Fig. 5 indicated that a greater amount of Fe3+ ions located around the structural defects like oxygen vacancies in the catalyst surface. Correlation of the values of D2/(D2 +D1) with the Fe content was plotted in Fig. 10 . When using the values of D2/(D2 +D1) to link the DBT conversion, Fig. 11 , we found that at different reaction temperatures (60, 70 and 80°C), three straight lines were obtained for the samples with Fe content 5, 10 and 15wt%. These results tell us that the DBT oxidation was proportional to the amount of the Fe3+ ions locating around the structural defects of the catalysts when the Fe content was less than or equal to 15wt%. Generally, the surface structural defects are active centers for surface adsorption and reactions. In most cases in heterogeneous catalysis, the structural defects also served as surface acidity sites. Therefore, we assumed that the adsorption and oxidation of DBTs preferentially took place in the acid sites and Fe3+ ions near the defects. When Fe content was greater than 15, such as 20 and 25wt%, the catalysts activity was not significantly increased because other factors (i) increase of the particles size; (ii) decrease of the dispersion of the Fe2O3 nanoparticles on the surface, and (iii) coverage of the surface Ti4+ by the Fe2O3, etc, negatively influenced the ODS activity. During ODS procedure, H2O2 oxidant was adsorbed on the active sites of the catalysts, forming active organometallic species in the catalyst surface. The adsorbed H2O2 species were coordinated with Fe3+ and Ti4+ to form peroxometallic complexes [45]. The OO bond in the peroxometallic complexes can be attacked by free electrons of S in DBTs to produce sulfoxides and sulfones. In comparison with H2O2, these surface peroxometallic complexes were more stable thus avoiding decomposition, and thus more effective for ODS reaction. The steric hindrance of DBTs was another factor that would affect the oxidation and extraction. The steric hindrance of the methyl groups in DBTs obstructed and weakened interaction between sulfur in DBTs and active oxygen species in the surface of the catalysts. This could explain the decreasing reactivity order of the DBTs with increasing of steric hindrance: DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT. In the biphasic system, there existed several interfaces: liquid-liquid interface (n-hexadecane/(acetonitrile+oxidant)), liquid-solid interface (n-hexadecane/catalyst, (acetonitrile+oxidant)/catalyst). Before the ODS reaction, DBTs were in the nonpolar oil phase (n-hexadecane), so ODS reactions predominately took place in the interface of catalyst/nonpolar phase after catalyst solid was added. However, without oxidant participation, the ODS efficiency was not high enough with catalysts alone; similarly, without catalyst, DBTs oxidation was rather low. Therefore, in the oil/catalyst interfaces, both oxidant and DBTs concentrated and contacted in the active sites of the catalyst to form peroxometallic complexes. Once sulfones were produced by transferring oxygen atom from the OO bond in the peroxometallic complexes to sulfur atom in the DBTs, they were immediately extracted by polar acetonitrile. We also measured the solubility of the DBTs in the mixture of n-hexadecane/acetonitrile (volume ratio=1:1). Results confirmed that sole extraction of heterocyclic organosulfur compounds from diesel fuel using acetonitrile as solvent was not applicable due to the low solubility of these compounds in acetonitrile. Only less than 16% of the DBTs were separated by extraction within 120min and high extraction efficiency needed multistage-extraction operation and took longer time. Because our reaction system was a mixture of nonpolar phase, polar phase, and catalyst solid, the small part of DBTs extracted into the polar phase could be also oxidized in the interface of (acetonitrile+oxidant)/catalyst. Based on our experimental results, a mechanism of DBTs oxidation/elimination was proposed in Scheme 1 . Oxidation reactions of DBTs chiefly took place in the liquid-solid interfaces (n-hexadecane/oxidant/catalyst and acetonitrile/oxidant/catalyst). DBTs oxidation in n-hexadecane and acetonitrile was based on the nucleophilic attack of the free electrons of the sulfur in the heterocyclic sulfur compounds towards the positively charged oxygen in the peroxometallic complexes in the surface of the catalysts to form sulfoxide. Subsequently, the formed sulfoxide underwent a second oxidation step by free electrons feedback to active oxygen species, forming sulfones. The produced sulfones were immediately extracted by acetonitrile and went into the polar phase. In the liquid-liquidliquid–liquid interface between n-hexadecane and acetonitrile, DBTs extraction and oxidation occurred simultaneously and the extracted DBTs could be also oxidized in the polar phase. 5 Conclusions The Fe/TiM catalysts showed a single pore size distribution with an average pore size between 21 and 24Å and pore wall thickness around 20Å. Incorporating Ti4+ and Fe3+ in the MCM-41 structure created the surface acidity and promoted the reducibility of the catalysts. Most of Fe3+ ions were highly dispersed on the surface of the catalysts but some of them inserted into the framework in different chemical environments. The reactivity of the DBTs decreased with increasing of the steric hindrance: DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT, under both acidic and basic conditions. Both iron content and surface acidity in the catalysts played important roles in the DBTs oxidation as they participated in the formation of the reactive oxygen species (peroxometallic complexes) with H2O2. The catalytic activity increased with increasing of surface acidity and the amount of iron ions around the structural defects of the catalysts. The present experiments also confirmed that sole extraction of heterocyclic organosulfur compounds from diesel using acetonitrile was not applicable due to low efficiency. The polar/nonpolar biphasic reaction system developed herein could effectively oxidize the sterically hindered sulfur-containing compounds and successfully extracted the produced sulfones into polar phase simultaneously within an acceptable operation time. coredata.dc:description: A series of FeOx/Ti-MCM-41 mesostructured catalysts were synthesized and characterized by the X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Mössbauer spectroscopy. The surface reducibility and acidity of the catalysts were measured by temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (TPR-H2) and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (TPR-NH3) methods. Incorporating Ti4+ in the MCM-41 framework and loading Fe2O3 in the surface of the catalysts would create the acid sites and enhance the surface oxygen reducibility. Most of Fe3+ ions were highly dispersed on the surface and some were inserted into the framework of the support with different structural environments. The amount of the Fe3+ ions locating around the structural defects increased as the Fe content increased. In a biphasic reaction system (n-hexadecane/acetonitrile), the oxidation/elimination of dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4-methyldibenzothiophene (4-MDBT), and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) could correlate perfectly with the surface acidity and the amount of iron ions around the structural defects of the catalysts. The reactivity of sulfur compounds decreased with increasing of the steric hindrance, showing an order as: DBT>4-MDBT>4,6-DMDBT. In the presence of catalyst and oxidant, the polar/non-polar biphasic reaction system developed herein could effectively oxidize the sterically hindered sulfur compounds and simultaneously extracted the produced sulfones from oil phase into polar phase.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidation/elimination of heterocyclic sulfur compounds in a biphasic system with mesostructured FeOx/Ti-MCM-41 catalysts
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
